sen.j: 神大市比売（かむおおいちひめ）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Kamu-oichi-hime is the god (the Shinto god) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
Kamu-oichi-hime is a Shinto goddess from Japanese mythology.
Kamu-oichi-hime is a Shinto goddess from Japanese mythology.

sen.j: 神社の祭神としては大歳御祖神（おおとしみおやのかみ）の神名で祀られることが多い。
sen.e: She is often enshrined as a deity under the name of Otoshimioya-no-kami.
She is often enshrined under the name of Otoshimioya-no-kami.
She is often enshrined under the name of Otoshimioya no Kami.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 日本神話では、『古事記』のスサノオの系図に登場する。
sen.e: In Japanese Mythology, she appears in the genealogical table of Susanoo in the "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters).
In Japanese mythology, she appears in the genealogical table of Susanoo in the "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters).
In Japanese mythology, she appears in the genealogical table of Susanoo in the "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: オオヤマヅミの子で、クシナダヒメの次に須佐之男命の妻となり、ウカノミタマ（稲荷神）と年神を産んだ。
sen.e: She was a daughter of Oyamazumi and became the second wife of Susanoo, after Kushinada-hime, and she gave birth to two sons, Ukanomitama, 'Inari-shin' (the god of harvest) and Toshinokami.
She was a daughter of Oyamazumi and became the second wife of Susanoo, after Kushinada-hime, giving birth to two sons, Ukanomitama, 'Inari-shin' (the god of the harvest) and Toshinokami.

She was a daughter of Oyamazumi and became the second wife of Susanoo, after Kushinada-hime, giving birth to two sons, Ukanomitama, 'Inari-shin' (the god of the harvest) and Otoshi no Kami (god of the incoming year).
sen.cmt: 年神 原文wikiを参照し、「大年神」とし、補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 2柱の御子神はどちらも農耕に関係のある神であり、神大市姫命もまた農耕神・食料神として信仰される。
sen.e: Two sons are the gods related to agriculture and Kamu-oichi-hime is also worshiped as the god of agriculture and food.
Both her sons have connections with agriculture and Kamu-oichi-hime is also worshiped as the goddess of agriculture and food.
Both her sons have connections with agriculture and Kamu-oichi-hime is also worshiped as the goddess of agriculture and food.

sen.j: 神名の「大市」は大和・伊勢・備中などにある地名に由来するものとみられるが、「神大市」を「神々しい立派な市」と解釈し、市場の守護神としても信仰される。
sen.e: It seems that her 'Shinmyo' (the name of god), "Oichi" was named after some places in some regions such as Yamato, Ise and Bicchu, and additionally, "Kamu-oichi" can be translated as a "godly, splendid market", therefore she is also worshiped as the guardian god for the market.

It seems that the "Oichi" part of her name comes from placenames in regions such as Yamato, Ise and Bicchu; additionally, since "Kamu-oichi" can be translated as a "godly, splendid market", she is also worshiped as the guardian god of markets.

It seems that the 'Oichi' part of her name comes from placenames in regions such as Yamato, Ise and Bicchu; additionally, since 'Kamu-oichi' can be translated as a 'godly, splendid market,' she is also worshiped as the guardian god of markets.

sen.j: 神大市姫命を祀る神社として、静岡浅間神社内の大歳御祖神社（静岡県静岡市葵区）、市比売神社（京都市下京区）、大内神社（岡山県備前市）などがある。
sen.e: There are some shrines where Kamu-oichi-hime is enshrined, such as Otoshimioya-jinja Shrine, inside of Shizuoka Asama-jinja Shrine (in Aoi Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture), Ichihime-jinja Shrine (in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City), and Ouchi-jinja Shrine (in Bizen City, Okayama Prefecture).

Shrines where Kamu-oichi-hime is worshiped include Otoshimioya-jinja Shrine, inside of Shizuoka Asama-jinja Shrine (in Aoi Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture), Ichihime-jinja Shrine (in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City), and Ouchi-jinja Shrine (in Bizen City, Okayama Prefecture).

Shrines where Kamu-oichi-hime is worshiped include Otoshimioya-jinja Shrine, inside of Shizuoka Sengen-jinja Shrine (Aoi Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture), Ichihime-jinja Shrine (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City), Ouchi-jinja Shrine (Bizen City, Okayama Prefecture), etc.
sen.cmt: 浅間神社→Sengen-jinja Shrineとしました。
